Description: Egyptian terracotta figure plaque of naked female (Isis-Hathor?) standing between columns. Mould-made and solid. Broken on three sides: legs, above head and to left side of woman, chipped in places. Coarse red-brown Nile silt with abundant mica and vegetal inclusions, dark grey core.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Allard Pierson Museum, Amsterdam. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Three similar pieces from Naukratis may come from same mould series (Cambridge, Museum of Classical Archaeology NA582; Amsterdam, Allard Pierson Museum 7483; Brussels, Musées Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire E.5018). Simple naked female figure plaques are common in Egypt during the Late period and in the Levant at contemporary Phoenician sites. Parallels are generally dated to the Late period and early Ptolemaic periods in Egypt, possibly to early Ptolemaic and though to be fertility figures or ex-voto in honour of, but not representing, Hathor (Török 1995, pl. 109, nos. 203-9, particularly no. 207; Bayer-Niemeier 1988, 148, no. 263-7, for wig, see no. 264; Weber 1914, no.199; Petrie 1909, pl. 35.7 and 12 from Memphis; Kaufmann 1913, fig. 69:3). Bayer-Niemeier identifies a clear ‘Pharaonic tradition’ clear with New Kingdom and Third Intermediate Period parallels from Medinet Habu (Teeter 2010, nos 24 to 26) and the Temple of Mut in Luxor (Waraksa 2009, no. 3) and similar examples of this Pharaonic tradition come from New Kingdom domestic religion parallels from Deir el-Medina, Sawâma and Amarna (ibid.). Similar figure plaques found at Naukratis in the British Museum (Bailey 2008, nos 3108 to 3110; Higgins 1954, 404; GR 1888,0601.113, GR1886,0401.1543, GR 1886,0401.1458), Cambridge (NA576, NA577, NA578, NA579, NA581, NA582, NA583, NA584), and by recent excavations at Naukratis by the Supreme Council of Archaeology (SCA) (unpublished). Bayer-Niemeier, E. 1988. Liebieghaus Museum Alter Plastik. Bildwerke der Sammlung Kaufmann, 1. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten. Melsungen. Kaufmann, C. M. 1913, Ägyptische Terrakotten der griechisch-römischen und koptischen Epoche, Cairo. Petrie, W.M.Fl. 1909a, Memphis I, London. Teeter, E. 2010, Baked Clay Figurines and Votive Beds from Medinet Habu, OIP 133, Chicago. Török, L. 1995. Hellenistic and Roman terracottas from Egypt. Roma. Waraksa, E. A. 2009, Female Figurines from the Mut Precinct: Context and Ritual Function, OBO 240, Göttingen. Weber, W. 1914, Die ägyptisch-griechischen Terrakotten. Königliche Museen zu Berlin, Mitteilungen aus der Ägyptischen Sammlung II., Berlin.
